title: We filed for bankruptcy ch7 hire a lawyer then filed ch13 didnâ€™t pay amount to trustees every month case got dismissed got
question: Letter from lender to pay in full amount,what can I do now since my attorney is no contacting me can I still save my house
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Foreclosure,Lawsuits and disputes
answers:
Creditor may foreclose on residence after C13 dismissed.
Review options, including re-filing C13 with BK counsel.

If you are delinquent on paying your mortgage, other than reaching an agreement with your lender to fix the problem, chapter 13 is the only way to go to prevent foreclosure. Chapter 7 is only going to give you 3 months to catch up while in chapter 13 can provide up to 5 years to do so. But if you can't or don't pay the ongoing mortgage payment plus extra to catch up, you are wasting everyone's time. There is no free ride here, so be realistic. Excuses don't hold water and you see what happens when you don't pay. Selling or swallowing a foreclosure might be the result. Hope this perspective helps!

The facts you stated aren't quite clear, since I'm not sure if you hired the attorney to file a chapter 7 and they filed under chapter 13 instead, or you had the attorney to file the chapter 7, it was completed and you filed your own chapter 13 later. That will make a difference on how difficult it will be to file a new chapter 13 to save your home and get immediate protection from the mortgage creditor.

As noted by others, the Automatic Stay is what stops a foreclosure sale. If you have file a prior case within a year, whether dismissed or completed, you must immediately file a Motion to Extend the Automatic Stay or the home may be sold after 30 days passes from the filing date. If you had 2 prior cases within a year, you don't get the Automatic Stay until the court orders it, so that is very time sensitive and puts you at a higher risk.

You need to have a consultation with an experienced bankruptcy attorney in your area immediately. Many attorney can do this over the phone. This forum is not the place to share your confidential information and get complete advice about your particular situation. Act now rather than right before a foreclosure sale if you really want to save your home.

You hired an attorney to do a Chapter 7? Did you get a "discharge order? or did the Chapter 7 get converted to a Chapter 13?

If you had an attorney and you did not make the payments in the Chapter 13 Plan which caused the dismissal, the attorney no longer represents you. His/her job is done. The attorney is not contacting you because they are done with your case. If you want real answers you need to get with a skilled bankruptcy attorney. If you are trying to save a home you need to see that attorney IMMEDIATELY.

Do yourself a huge favor and see a quality bankruptcy attorney to find out what can be done for you and what is protected. Your case would be filed in the Bankruptcy Court in Sacramento. I would recommend you find a quality bankruptcy attorney by looking at Avvo's ratings for Sacramento attorneys.

You could also look at the CA State bar website for a Certified Bankruptcy Law Specialist in Sacramento. Most attorneys will give you are free initial consultation. I have provided a link to the state bar below.

Another potential source for finding a good attorney would be through a search of the National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys (NACBA.org) to find a good local attorney. Again, I have provided a link below. You could also go to Yelp reviews or the Better Business Bureau of Northern CA or even google reviews of the attorneys.


No matter how good an attorney is rated, if you are not comfortable with the attorney when you meet, move on to another attorney. Also, if the attorney uses a paralegal to do the initial appointment, move on because you are just a number and a dollar sign. If this is how you are treated when they are trying to get your money, you can be certain it is not going to get better after they get your money.

Do NOT use an attorney that does anything other than bankruptcy and consumer law and/or foreclosure law. Part-time bankruptcy attorneys are, sadly, almost never expert enough to do the job right. This is a specialized field and you should go with an attorney who practices solely in that specialty. Never hire to veterinarian's assistant to do brain surgery on you and never hire a non-specialist to do a specialists job. Get the right attorney to begin with.

I hope this helps you.

Click the Avvo tab "Find a Lawyer" in your area. Contact 3-4 until you find one who promptly returns your call, understands what is needed to remedy you situation and who offers a free consultation. Good luck.
Whether you can save your house depends on a lot of facts we don't have ... but the first step is probably to file another Ch13 (but do it right this time).

You may be able to file another ch13. You'll probably need to file a motion to impose or extend the stay at the same time you file a new case and you'll need to make the payment called for by your plan. You'll need an attorney.
